text: Jesus Taken to Pilate

Now \add when it\add*\ef + \fr 27:1 \ft ﻿*Here “\add when\add*” is supplied as a component of the temporal genitive absolute participle (“was”) \ef* was early morning, all the chief priests and the elders of the people took counsel against Jesus in order to put him to death.

And \add after\add*\ef + \fr 27:2 \ft ﻿*Here “\add after\add*” is supplied as a component of the participle (“tying”) which is understood as temporal \ef* tying him up, they led \add him\add*\ef + \fr 27:2 \ft ﻿*Here the direct object is supplied from context in the English translation \ef* away and handed \add him\add*\ef + \fr 27:2 \ft ﻿*Here the direct object is supplied from context in the English translation \ef* over to Pilate the governor.
The Suicide of Judas Iscariot

Then \add when\add*\ef + \fr 27:3 \ft ﻿*Here “\add when\add*” is supplied as a component of the participle (“saw”) which is understood as temporal \ef* Judas, the one who had betrayed him, saw that he had been condemned, he regretted \add what he had done\add*\ef + \fr 27:3 \ft ﻿*Here the direct object is supplied from context in the English translation \ef* \add and\add*\ef + \fr 27:3 \ft ﻿*Here “\add and\add*” is supplied because the previous participle (“regretted”) has been translated as a finite verb \ef* returned the thirty silver coins to the chief priests and elders,

saying, “I have sinned \add by\add*\ef + \fr 27:4 \ft ﻿*Here “\add by\add*” is supplied as a component of the participle (“betraying”) which is understood as means \ef* betraying innocent blood!” But they said, “What \add is that\add* to us? You see to \add it\add*!”\ef + \fr 27:4 \ft *Here the direct object is supplied from context in the English translation \ef*

And throwing the silver coins into the temple he departed. And he went away \add and\add*\ef + \fr 27:5 \ft ﻿*Here “\add and\add*” is supplied because the previous participle (“went away”) has been translated as a finite verb \ef* hanged himself.

But the chief priests took the silver coins \add and\add*\ef + \fr 27:6 \ft ﻿*Here “\add and\add*” is supplied because the previous participle (“took”) has been translated as a finite verb \ef* said, “It is not permitted to put them into the temple treasury, because it is ⸤blood money⸥.”\f + \fr 27:6 \ft Literally “the price of blood” \f*

And \add after\add*\ef + \fr 27:7 \ft ﻿*Here “\add after\add*” is supplied as a component of the participle (“taking”) which is understood as temporal \ef* taking counsel, they purchased ⸤with⸥\f + \fr 27:7 \ft Literally “for” \f* them the Potter’s Field, for a burial place for strangers.
(For this reason that field has been called the Field of Blood until today.)

Then what was spoken by the prophet Jeremiah was fulfilled, who said, “And they took the thirty silver coins, the price of the one who had been priced, \add on\add* whom a price had been set by the sons of Israel,

and they gave them for the potter’s field, just as the Lord directed me.”\f + \fr 27:10 \ft A quotation from various passages in Jeremiah including \xt 18:2–6 \ft ; \xt 19:1–13 \ft ; \xt 32:6–15 \ft ; see also \xt Zech 11:12–13 \ft \f*
Jesus Before Pilate
So Jesus stood before the governor, and the governor asked him, saying, “Are you the king of the Jews?” And Jesus said, “You say \add so\add*.”
And ⸤when he was being accused⸥\f + \fr 27:12 \ft Literally “in the him being accused” \f* by the chief priests and elders he answered nothing.
Then Pilate said to him, “Do you not hear how many \add things\add* they are testifying against you?”
And he did not reply to him, not even with reference to one statement, so that the governor was very astonished.
Pilate Releases Barabbas
Now at each feast, the governor was accustomed to release one prisoner to the crowd—the one whom they wanted.

And at that time they had a notorious prisoner named Jesus\f + \fr 27:16 \ft Although many manuscripts omit “Jesus” here, it is so hard to explain why a scribe would have added it that the reading is probably original \f* Barabbas.\f + \fr 27:16 \ft “Barabbas” means “son of the father” in Aramaic \f*

So \add after\add*\ef + \fr 27:17 \ft ﻿*Here “\add after\add*” is supplied as a component of the temporal genitive absolute participle (“had assembled”) \ef* they had assembled, Pilate said to them, “Whom do you want me to release for you—Jesus\f + \fr 27:17 \ft Although many manuscripts omit “Jesus” here, it is so hard to explain why a scribe would have added it that the reading is probably original \f* Barabbas or Jesus who is called Christ?”
(For he knew that they had handed him over because of envy.

And \add while\add*\ef + \fr 27:19 \ft ﻿*Here “\add while\add*” is supplied as a component of the temporal genitive absolute participle (“was sitting”) \ef* he was sitting on the judgment seat, his wife sent \add a message\add*\ef + \fr 27:19 \ft ﻿*Here the direct object is supplied from context in the English translation \ef* to him, saying, “⸤Have nothing to do with that righteous man⸥,\f + \fr 27:19 \ft Literally “nothing to you and to that righteous man” \f* for I have suffered much as a result of a dream today because of him.”)
But the chief priests and the elders persuaded the crowds that they should ask for Barabbas and put Jesus to death.

So the governor answered \add and\add*\ef + \fr 27:21 \ft ﻿*Here “\add and\add*” is supplied because the previous participle (“answered”) has been translated as a finite verb \ef* said to them, “Which of the two do you want me to release for you?” And they said, “Barabbas!”
Pilate said to them, “What then should I do \add with\add* Jesus, the one who is called Christ?” They all said, “Let him be crucified!”

And he said, “Why? What wrong has he done?” But they began to shout\ef + \fr 27:23 \ft ﻿*The imperfect tense has been translated as ingressive here (“began to shout”) \ef* even louder, saying, “Let him be crucified!”

So Pilate, \add when he\add*\ef + \fr 27:24 \ft ﻿*Here “\add when\add*” is supplied as a component of the participle (“saw”) which is understood as temporal \ef* saw that he was accomplishing nothing, but instead an uproar was developing, took water \add and\add*\ef + \fr 27:24 \ft ﻿*Here “\add and\add*” is supplied because the previous participle (“took”) has been translated as a finite verb \ef* washed his\f + \fr 27:24 \ft Literally “the”; the Greek article is used here as a possessive pronoun \f* hands before the crowd, saying, “I am innocent of the blood of this man. You see to \add it\add*!”\ef + \fr 27:24 \ft *Here the direct object is supplied from context in the English translation \ef*

And all the people answered \add and\add*\ef + \fr 27:25 \ft ﻿*Here “\add and\add*” is supplied because the previous participle (“answered”) has been translated as a finite verb \ef* said, “His blood \add be\add* on us and on our children!”

Then he released Barabbas for them, but \add after\add*\ef + \fr 27:26 \ft ﻿*Here “\add after\add*” is supplied as a component of the participle (“flogged”) which is understood as temporal \ef* he had Jesus flogged, he handed \add him\add*\ef + \fr 27:26 \ft ﻿*Here the direct object is supplied from context in the English translation \ef* over so that he could be crucified.
Jesus Is Mocked

Then the soldiers of the governor took Jesus into the governor’s residence \add and\add*\ef + \fr 27:27 \ft ﻿*Here “\add and\add*” is supplied because the previous participle (“took”) has been translated as a finite verb \ef* gathered the whole cohort to him.

And they stripped him \add and\add*\ef + \fr 27:28 \ft ﻿*Here “\add and\add*” is supplied because the previous participle (“stripped”) has been translated as a finite verb \ef* put a scarlet military cloak around him,

and weaving a crown of thorns, they put \add it\add*\ef + \fr 27:29 \ft ﻿*Here the direct object is supplied from context in the English translation \ef* on his head, and \add put\add*\f + \fr 27:29 \ft This is an understood repetition of the verb from earlier in the verse \f* a reed in his right hand. And kneeling down before him, they mocked him, saying, “Hail, king of the Jews!”

And they spat on him \add and\add*\ef + \fr 27:30 \ft ﻿*Here “\add and\add*” is supplied because the previous participle (“spat”) has been translated as a finite verb \ef* took the reed and repeatedly struck\f + \fr 27:30 \ft The imperfect tense has been translated as iterative here (“repeatedly struck”) \f* \add him\add*\ef + \fr 27:30 \ft ﻿*Here the direct object is supplied from context in the English translation \ef* on his head.

And when they had mocked him, they stripped him of the military cloak and put his \add own\add* clothes on him, and led him away in order to crucify \add him\add*.\ef + \fr 27:31 \ft *Here the direct object is supplied from context in the English translation \ef*
Jesus Is Crucified

And \add as they\add*\ef + \fr 27:32 \ft ﻿*Here “\add as\add*” is supplied as a component of the participle (“were going out”) which is understood as temporal \ef* were going out, they found a man of Cyrene ⸤named⸥\f + \fr 27:32 \ft Literally “by name” \f* Simon. They forced this man to carry his cross.

And \add when they\add*\ef + \fr 27:33 \ft ﻿*Here “\add when\add*” is supplied as a component of the participle (“came”) which is understood as temporal \ef* came to a place called \tl Golgotha\tl* (which ⸤means Place of a Skull⸥),\f + \fr 27:33 \ft Literally “is called Place of a Skull” \f*

they gave him wine mixed with gall to drink, and \add when he\add*\ef + \fr 27:34 \ft ﻿*Here “\add when\add*” is supplied as a component of the participle (“tasted”) which is understood as temporal \ef* tasted \add it\add*\ef + \fr 27:34 \ft ﻿*Here the direct object is supplied from context in the English translation \ef* he did not want to drink \add it\add*.\ef + \fr 27:34 \ft *Here the direct object is supplied from context in the English translation \ef*

And \add when they\add*\ef + \fr 27:35 \ft ﻿*Here “\add when\add*” is supplied as a component of the participle (“had crucified”) which is understood as temporal \ef* had crucified him, they divided his clothes among themselves\ef + \fr 27:35 \ft ﻿*Here “among themselves” reflects the middle voice of the verb “divided” \ef* \add by\add*\ef + \fr 27:35 \ft ﻿*Here “\add by\add*” is supplied as a component of the participle (“casting”) which is understood as means \ef* casting lots.

And they sat down \add and\add*\ef + \fr 27:36 \ft ﻿*Here “\add and\add*” is supplied because the previous participle (“sat down”) has been translated as a finite verb \ef* were watching over him there.
And they put above his head the charge against him ⸤in writing⸥:\f + \fr 27:37 \ft Literally “written” \f* “This is Jesus, the king of the Jews.”
Then two robbers were crucified with him, one on \add his\add* right and one on \add his\add* left.
And those who passed by reviled him, shaking their heads

and saying, “The one who would destroy the temple and rebuild \add it\add*\ef + \fr 27:40 \ft ﻿*Here the direct object is supplied from context in the English translation \ef* in three days, save yourself! If you are the Son of God, come down from the cross!”

In the same way also the chief priests, along with the scribes and elders, were mocking \add him\add*,\ef + \fr 27:41 \ft *Here the direct object is supplied from context in the English translation \ef* saying,
“He saved others; he is not able to save himself! He is the king of Israel! Let him come down now from the cross, and we will believe in him!
He trusts in God; let him deliver him now if he wants to,\f + \fr 27:43 \ft Or “let him deliver \fq him \ft now if he wants him” \f* because he said, ‘I am the Son of God’!”
And in the same \add way\add* even the robbers who were crucified with him were reviling him.
Jesus Dies on the Cross
Now from the sixth hour, darkness came over all the land until the ninth hour.

And about the ninth hour Jesus cried out with a loud voice, saying, “\qs Eli, Eli, lema sabachthani?\qs*” (that is, “My God, my God, why have you forsaken me?”)\f + \fr 27:46 \ft A quotation from \xt Ps 22:1 \ft \f*

And some of those who were standing there, \add when they\add*\ef + \fr 27:47 \ft ﻿*Here “\add when\add*” is supplied as a component of the participle (“heard”) which is understood as temporal \ef* heard \add it\add*,\ef + \fr 27:47 \ft *Here the direct object is supplied from context in the English translation \ef* said, “This man is summoning Elijah!”

And immediately one of them ran and took a sponge and filled \add it\add*\ef + \fr 27:48 \ft ﻿*Here the direct object is supplied from context in the English translation \ef* with sour wine and put \add it\add*\ef + \fr 27:48 \ft ﻿*Here the direct object is supplied from context in the English translation \ef* on a reed \add and\add*\ef + \fr 27:48 \ft ﻿*Here “\add and\add*” is supplied because the previous participles (“ran … took … filled … put”) have been translated as finite verbs \ef* gave \add it\add*\ef + \fr 27:48 \ft ﻿*Here the direct object is supplied from context in the English translation \ef* to him to drink.
But the others said, “Leave \add him\add*\ef + \fr 27:49 \ft ﻿*Here the direct object is supplied from context in the English translation \ef* alone! let us see if Elijah is coming to save him.”

And Jesus cried out again with a loud voice \add and\add*\ef + \fr 27:50 \ft ﻿*Here “\add and\add*” is supplied because the previous participle (“cried out”) has been translated as a finite verb \ef* gave up his\ef + \fr 27:50 \ft ﻿*Literally “the”; the Greek article is used here as a possessive pronoun \ef* spirit.
And behold, the curtain of the temple was torn in two from top to bottom, and the earth shook and the rocks were split.
And the tombs were opened, and many bodies of the saints who had fallen asleep were raised,
and coming out of the tombs after his resurrection, they went into the holy city and appeared to many.

Now the centurion and those with him who were guarding Jesus, \add when they\add*\ef + \fr 27:54 \ft ﻿*Here “\add when\add*” is supplied as a component of the participle (“saw”) which is understood as temporal \ef* saw the earthquake and the things that took place, were extremely frightened, saying, “Truly this man was God’s Son!”
And there were many women there, observing from a distance, who had followed Jesus from Galilee, serving him,
among whom were Mary Magdalene, and Mary the mother of James and Joseph, and the mother of the sons of Zebedee.
Jesus Is Buried
Now \add when it\add* was evening, a rich man from Arimathea named Joseph came, who also was a disciple of Jesus himself.

This man approached Pilate \add and\add*\ef + \fr 27:58 \ft ﻿*Here “\add and\add*” is supplied because the previous participle (“approached”) has been translated as a finite verb \ef* asked for the body of Jesus. Then Pilate ordered \add it\add*\ef + \fr 27:58 \ft ﻿*Here the direct object is supplied from context in the English translation \ef* to be given \add to him\add*.\ef + \fr 27:58 \ft *The words “\add to him\add*” are not in the Greek text but are implied \ef*

And Joseph took the body \add and\add*\ef + \fr 27:59 \ft ﻿*Here “\add and\add*” is supplied because the previous participle (“took”) has been translated as a finite verb \ef* wrapped it in a clean linen cloth,

and placed it in his \add own\add* new tomb that he had cut in the rock. And he rolled a large stone to the entrance of the tomb \add and\add*\ef + \fr 27:60 \ft ﻿*Here “\add and\add*” is supplied because the previous participle (“rolled”) has been translated as a finite verb \ef* went away.
Now Mary Magdalene and the other Mary were there, sitting opposite the tomb.
The Tomb Is Sealed and Guarded
Now \add on\add* the next day, which is after the day of preparation, the chief priests and the Pharisees assembled before Pilate,

saying, “Sir, we remember that \add while\add*\ef + \fr 27:63 \ft ﻿*Here “\add while\add*” is supplied as a component of the participle (“alive”) which is understood as temporal \ef* that deceiver was still alive he said, ‘After three days I will rise.’

Therefore give orders that the tomb be made secure until the third day, lest his disciples come \add and\add*\ef + \fr 27:64 \ft ﻿*Here “\add and\add*” is supplied because the previous participle (“come”) has been translated as a finite verb \ef* steal him and tell the people, ‘He has been raised from the dead,’ and the last deception will be worse than the first.”

Pilate said to them, “You have a guard of soldiers. Go, make \add it\add*\ef + \fr 27:65 \ft ﻿*Here the direct object is supplied from context in the English translation \ef* as secure as you know how.”

So they went with the guard of soldiers \add and\add*\ef + \fr 27:66 \ft ﻿*Here “\add and\add*” is supplied because the previous participle (“went”) has been translated as a finite verb \ef* made the tomb secure \add by\add*\ef + \fr 27:66 \ft ﻿*Here “\add by\add*” is supplied as a component of the participle (“sealing”) which is understood as means \ef* sealing the stone.
